slides.title: Introduction to ClaimCenter
slides.notes: Welcome to the Guidewire ClaimCenter training session. In this lesson, we'll explore the claims process, focusing on the claim lifecycle, exposure management, and financial transactions.
slides.narration: Welcome to the Guidewire ClaimCenter training session! Today, we'll embark on a journey through the claims process, delving into the intricacies of the claim lifecycle, exposure management, and financial transactions. As developers, understanding these concepts will empower us to build robust solutions that streamline claims handling and enhance user experiences. Let's get started and explore how ClaimCenter enables seamless claims management.
slides.ocrText: The Claims Process

slides.title: Understanding Claims Processing
slides.notes: Claims processing involves several stages, from initial reporting to final settlement. Each stage requires careful handling of data and coordination among various user roles.
slides.narration: Claims processing is a dynamic journey, beginning with the initial report and culminating in the final settlement. Each stage demands precise data management and coordination among different user roles within ClaimCenter. As we proceed, we'll uncover how ClaimCenter orchestrates these stages, ensuring efficient and accurate claims handling.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives • Describe the role of ClaimCenter in managing

claims

ClaimCenter

ClaimCenter

• Describe the general workflow of a claim

slides.title: Key Components of ClaimCenter
slides.notes: Explore the primary components of ClaimCenter that facilitate claims management, including the claim file, exposures, and financial transactions.
slides.narration: Let's explore the key components that make ClaimCenter a powerful tool for claims management. Central to this is the claim file, which acts as a repository for all claim-related data. We'll also examine exposures and financial transactions, crucial elements that help manage the financial aspects of a claim effectively.

slides.title: ClaimCenter Internal User Types
slides.originalNotes:
ClaimCenter Internal User Types
ClaimCenter (CC) is a browser- based application that enables users to participate in claims processing. The most common internal user types of ClaimCenter at a carrier are shown in this slide and these are the primary user types that will be discussed in this course.
slides.notes:
ClaimCenter Internal User Types
ClaimCenter (CC) is a browser- based application that enables users to participate in claims processing. The most common internal user types of ClaimCenter at a carrier are shown in this slide and these are the primary user types that will be discussed in this course.
slides.narration: ClaimCenter, being a browser-based application, facilitates the participation of various internal user types in claims processing. Key roles include adjusters, supervisors, and claims managers, each contributing uniquely to the lifecycle of a claim. Understanding these roles will help us develop features that cater to their specific needs and improve the overall workflow.

slides.title: The Value Proposition of ClaimCenter
slides.originalNotes:
The value proposition of ClaimCenter
ClaimCenter is a claim-centric solution. All of the data pertaining to a claim is centralized in the claim file. This includes information on policies, financials, diaries, documents, parties involved, and litigation. All users have an integrated and holistic view of the claim.

ClaimCenter facilitates collaboration among claims workers by providing one centralized location where all information needed to adjudicate the claim can be uniformly worked on and shared concurrently. ClaimCenter provides a wide span of control for supervisors by providing them with real-time team statistics and the ability to not only manage the team but to also control and direct team activities.
slides.notes:

ClaimCenter facilitates collaboration among claims workers by providing one centralized location where all information needed to adjudicate the claim can be uniformly worked on and shared concurrently. ClaimCenter provides a wide span of control for supervisors by providing them with real-time team statistics and the ability to not only manage the team but to also control and direct team activities.
slides.narration: ClaimCenter stands out as a claim-centric solution, centralizing all data related to a claim within a single file. This holistic view encompasses policies, financials, diaries, documents, parties involved, and litigation. By unifying these elements, ClaimCenter enables seamless collaboration and decision-making, empowering claims workers with comprehensive insights at every step.

slides.title: Integrated Collaboration in ClaimCenter
slides.notes: ClaimCenter facilitates collaboration among claims workers by providing one centralized location where all information needed to adjudicate the claim can be uniformly worked on and shared concurrently. ClaimCenter provides a wide span of control for supervisors by providing them with real-time team statistics and the ability to not only manage the team but to also control and direct team activities.
slides.narration: In ClaimCenter, collaboration is key. By providing a centralized platform, claims workers can uniformly access and share information needed for claim adjudication. This integration extends to supervisors, who gain real-time insights into team performance, enabling effective management and control over team activities. Such capabilities streamline the claims process and enhance operational efficiency.

slides.title: Data Centralization in ClaimCenter
slides.notes: Centralized data storage in ClaimCenter ensures all claim-related information is easily accessible and manageable, reducing redundancy and errors.
slides.narration: Data centralization in ClaimCenter is pivotal for reducing redundancy and minimizing errors. By ensuring that all claim-related information is stored in one accessible location, ClaimCenter enhances data accuracy and consistency. This approach empowers users to manage claims with confidence, knowing they have the most up-to-date information at their fingertips.

slides.title: Authentication and Authorization
slides.notes: Authentication is the process of verifying a user is who he or she claims to be. Authorization is the process of determining which objects a user is allowed to view and edit and what actions a user is allowed to take.
slides.narration: Authentication and authorization are crucial security mechanisms in ClaimCenter. Authentication verifies user identity, typically through a username and password, while authorization determines the user's access rights within the system. Proper configuration of these processes ensures secure and efficient user interactions, safeguarding sensitive claim data.

slides.title: Login Process in ClaimCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Authentication and authorization
Authentication is the process of verifying a user is who he or she claims to be. Authorization is the process of determining which objects a user is allowed to view and edit and what actions a user is allowed to take- When an end user attempts to log on to an application, the following occurs:

The user supplies their username and password to ClaimCenter via the login page.

ClaimCenter queries the authentication system (which could be a separate system accessed through an integration point or the ClaimCenter database itself) to authenticate the user.

ClaimCenter queries the ClaimCenter database to determine permissions are assigned to the user and what the user's start page is Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log in.
ClaimCenter renders the appropriate startup view with permissions appropriate for that user.

Out-of-box, authentication is managed through the ClaimCenter database. There is a table in the database which stores usernames and password. (The system can also be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure.)

ClaimCenter can be configured to lock an account after a user attempts to log in a certain number of times without providing the correct password. (This feature is designed to prevent someone circumventing the authentication process to illegally log on to the application.) When an account is locked, it must be unlocked by a manager. In the base application, the number of attempts before locking the account is 3, but this number can be configured.
slides.notes:
Authentication and authorization
Authentication is the process of verifying a user is who he or she claims to be. Authorization is the process of determining which objects a user is allowed to view and edit and what actions a user is allowed to take- When an end user attempts to log on to an application, the following occurs:

ClaimCenter queries the authentication system (which could be a separate system accessed through an integration point or the ClaimCenter database itself) to authenticate the user.

ClaimCenter queries the ClaimCenter database to determine permissions are assigned to the user and what the user's start page is Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log in.
ClaimCenter renders the appropriate startup view with permissions appropriate for that user.

Out-of-box, authentication is managed through the ClaimCenter database. There is a table in the database which stores usernames and password. (The system can also be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure.)

ClaimCenter can be configured to lock an account after a user attempts to log in a certain number of times without providing the correct password. In the base application, the number of attempts before locking the account is 3, but this number can be configured.
slides.narration: The login process in ClaimCenter begins with the user providing their credentials on the login page. The system then authenticates these credentials, either through its own database or an integrated authentication system. This ensures that only authorized users gain access to the system, maintaining the integrity and security of claim data.

slides.title: Role-Based Access Control
slides.notes: ClaimCenter queries the ClaimCenter database to determine permissions are assigned to the user and what the user's start page is. Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to and which actions the user can perform.
slides.narration: Once authenticated, ClaimCenter uses role-based access control to tailor the user experience. By querying the database, it determines the user's permissions and sets the appropriate start page. This setup defines the screens a user can access and the actions they can perform, ensuring a secure and efficient workflow that aligns with their responsibilities.

slides.title: Account Security in ClaimCenter
slides.notes: ClaimCenter can be configured to lock an account after a user attempts to log in a certain number of times without providing the correct password.
slides.narration: ClaimCenter enhances security by implementing account lockout policies. If a user fails to log in after several attempts, the account is locked to prevent unauthorized access. This feature acts as a safeguard against brute-force attacks, ensuring that only legitimate users can access the system. Managers have the ability to unlock accounts when necessary, providing a balance between security and accessibility.

slides.title: Claim Summary Overview
slides.notes: The Claim Summary panel provides a high-level view of a claim, including basic details, financials, and high-risk indicators.
slides.narration: The Claim Summary panel in ClaimCenter offers a comprehensive snapshot of a claim at a glance. It encompasses essential information such as claim duration, financials, and high-risk indicators. This panel is a powerful tool for adjusters, allowing them to quickly assess the status and critical elements of a claim, facilitating informed decision-making and efficient claim management.

slides.title: Basics Section in Claim Summary
slides.notes: Basics — This section shows how long the claim has been open at a glance. It also shows the target closure days for a claim of this type. It includes a description of the claim.
slides.narration: In the Claim Summary, the Basics section provides an immediate overview of the claim's timeline, highlighting how long the claim has been open and the target closure days. It also includes a brief description of the claim, offering context for the adjuster. This information is crucial for prioritizing tasks and managing claim workloads effectively.

slides.title: Financials Section in Claim Summary
slides.notes: Financials — This section gives a high-level view of the current state of the financials for this claim. It shows the Gross incurred, which is a summary of the recorded exposures and reserve lines, as well as what has been paid on the claim to date.
slides.narration: The Financials section in the Claim Summary is key to understanding the financial health of a claim. It provides a high-level view of gross incurred amounts, summarizing recorded exposures and reserve lines, alongside payments made to date. This snapshot is invaluable for adjusters in managing the financial aspects of claims and ensuring accountability.

slides.title: High-Risk Indicators in Claim Summary
slides.notes: High-Risk Indicators — This section shows any high-risk indicators such as In Litigation, Coverage in Question, or other flags.
slides.narration: Identifying high-risk factors is crucial in claim management. The High-Risk Indicators section highlights potential red flags such as litigation status or coverage questions. By bringing these risks to the forefront, ClaimCenter assists adjusters in proactively addressing challenges and mitigating potential complications in the claim lifecycle.

slides.title: Navigating Claims with the Sidebar
slides.notes: The Sidebar shows all of the menu links that are available to the current user on this claim. The adjuster uses this menu to navigate to specific parts of the claim file to see or update details about the claim.
slides.narration: For efficient navigation, the Sidebar in ClaimCenter provides adjusters with quick access to all relevant claim file sections. This feature streamlines the process of updating or reviewing claim details, ensuring that adjusters can focus on the most pressing tasks without getting bogged down by navigation challenges.

slides.title: Loss Details in Claims
slides.originalNotes:
Claim Summary
There are three sections of the Claim Summary panel:

Basics — This section shows how long the claim has been open at a glance. It also shows the target closure days for a claim of this type. It includes a description of the claim.

Financials — This section gives a high-level view of the current state of the financials for this claim. It shows the Gross incurred, which is a summary of the recorded exposures and reserve lines, as well as what has been paid on the claim to date.

High-Risk Indicators — This section shows any high-risk indicators such as In Litigation, Coverage in Question, or other flags.

The Sidebar shows all of the menu links that are available to the current user on this claim The adjuster uses this menu to navigate to specific parts of the claim file to see or update details about the claim.
slides.notes:
Claim Summary
There are three sections of the Claim Summary panel:

Basics — This section shows how long the claim has been open at a glance. It also shows the target closure days for a claim of this type. It includes a description of the claim.

Financials — This section gives a high-level view of the current state of the financials for this claim. It shows the Gross incurred, which is a summary of the recorded exposures and reserve lines, as well as what has been paid on the claim to date.

High-Risk Indicators — This section shows any high-risk indicators such as In Litigation, Coverage in Question, or other flags.

The Sidebar shows all of the menu links that are available to the current user on this claim The adjuster uses this menu to navigate to specific parts of the claim file to see or update details about the claim.
slides.narration: In the adjudication process, adjusters play a critical role in enriching claim data. They can add various details, such as witnesses or new claimants, to the Parties Involved section. This flexibility ensures that all pertinent information is captured, aiding in thorough investigations and accurate claim resolutions.

slides.title: Key Loss Details
slides.notes: Here are just a few of the items that an adjuster may add to a claim.
slides.narration: Adjusters can enhance a claim by adding key details such as accident descriptions, injured parties' contact information, and injury specifics. These inputs are vital for assessing the claim's validity and determining appropriate compensability factors, ultimately guiding the resolution process.

slides.title: Employment and Compensability Details
slides.notes: Employment details — Data that helps determine how much "lost time" coverage may be required. Compensability factors — Data that helps determine whether this injury is legitimately covered by the Worker’s Compensation policy.
slides.narration: Employment and compensability details are pivotal in claims adjudication. Employment data assists in calculating necessary "lost time" coverage, while compensability factors help verify if an injury falls under a policy's coverage. These insights are crucial for adjusters to make informed decisions and expedite claims processing.

slides.title: Financial Transactions in ClaimCenter
slides.notes: Financial transactions manage the monetary aspects of claims, including payments, reserves, and recoveries.
slides.narration: In ClaimCenter, financial transactions are the backbone of managing the monetary aspects of claims. They encompass payments, reserves, and recoveries, each playing a crucial role in maintaining the financial integrity of a claim. Understanding these elements allows developers to ensure that financial processes are seamless and compliant with business rules.

slides.title: Financials Approval Workflow
slides.originalNotes:
Loss Details
During the adjudication process and adjuster may add information to the claim. The changes could range from adding a witness to Parties Involved, to adding additional claimants.

Here are just a few of the items that an adjuster may add to a claim.

Description — What happened? Where?

Details of the injured worker — Who was injured? Can we contact him, and how?

Details of the injury — What is injured, and how badly? How did it happen?

Employment details — Data that helps determine how much "lost time" coverage may be required.

Compensability factors — Data that helps determine whether this injury is legitimately covered by the Worker’s Compensation policy.
slides.notes:
Loss Details
During the adjudication process and adjuster may add information to the claim. The changes could range from adding a witness to Parties Involved, to adding additional claimants.

Here are just a few of the items that an adjuster may add to a claim.

Description — What happened? Where?

Details of the injured worker — Who was injured? Can we contact him, and how?

Details of the injury — What is injured, and how badly? How did it happen?

Employment details — Data that helps determine how much "lost time" coverage may be required.

Compensability factors — Data that helps determine whether this injury is legitimately covered by the Worker’s Compensation policy.
slides.narration: The approval workflow in ClaimCenter is designed to ensure accountability in financial transactions. Transactions that meet certain criteria bypass approval and are processed immediately, while others enter a "pending approval" state. This mechanism ensures that more complex transactions are reviewed, maintaining the financial integrity and compliance of the claims process.

slides.title: Reassigning Objects in ClaimCenter
slides.notes: When a claim is reassigned, all exposures and activities belonging to the original owner are also reassigned to the new owner.
slides.narration: Reassigning objects within ClaimCenter is an integral part of managing workloads and adjusting to organizational changes. When a claim is reassigned, associated exposures and activities move to the new owner, maintaining continuity. This feature ensures that claims are managed efficiently, even as personnel or priorities shift.

slides.title: Maintaining Activity Ownership
slides.notes: Any exposure or activity belonging to a user other than the claim owner remains with that user.
slides.narration: In ClaimCenter, maintaining activity ownership is crucial for preserving accountability. When a claim is reassigned, activities belonging to users other than the claim owner remain with their original owners. This approach ensures that tasks are completed by those best equipped to handle them, enhancing operational efficiency.

slides.title: Conclusion and Next Steps
slides.notes: Summarize key takeaways from the lesson and introduce the next lesson on claim maintenance.
slides.narration: As we conclude this introduction to the claims process in ClaimCenter, remember the importance of understanding the claim lifecycle, exposure management, and financial transactions. These elements are foundational to developing effective claims solutions. Up next, we'll dive into the specifics of claim maintenance, exploring how ongoing claim management is handled within ClaimCenter. Stay tuned for more insights and practical applications!

slides.title: Reassigning objects
slides.originalNotes:
Reassigning objects
When a claim is reassigned, all exposures and activities belonging to the original owner are also reassigned to the new owner. Any exposure or activity belonging to a user other than the claim owner remains with that user.

When an exposure is reassigned, all activities associated with the exposure that belonged to the original owner are also reassigned to the new owner. Any activity associated with the exposure which belongs to a user other than the claim owner remains with that user.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
When a user attempts to log into ClaimCenter, what three pieces of
Fa information does the application attempt to determine?
1.Whether or not the user can be authenticated,
2.What are the user's roles (permissions), and
3.What is the user's startup page.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
a What is the purpose of an exposure?
•
An exposure is used to track potential payments on one coverage, for one claimant.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
What are two mechanisms used to determine if a transaction requires
of approval?
•4
-S e S  e  e H

questionData.question: What are two mechanisms used to determine if a transaction requires approval?
questionData.answer:
Authority limits and transaction approval rules are used to identify which transactions
require approval.
